pros:
All colleagues are very nice, helpful and friendly.

cons:
Lack of opportunities for progression/promotion. Limited opportunities to branch out and work within other teams to understand wider organisation. 
Very little/no discussion around goals and objectives. 
Payment level unfair for huge amount of work. Work often assigned last minute and completion expected immediately. 
Understaffed due to cuts/restructuring, as such workload was often too heavy for 1 person to manage but still expected even after raising this as an ongoing concern. 
Work often very monotonous and menial, very limited opportunities to up skill. 
Hierarchy structure means management etc. are delegating tasks but not getting actively involved and sharing workload when at full capacity.

pros:
- The people are the best thing about it, but in truth most of the amazing people have all left as they realise how terrible A.I is. 
-The ability to work from home and not be forced into the office during covid was also a plus.
cons:
- The Salary - the salary by rung is completely ridiculous, with the difference between roles and salary jumping drastically at director level and above. There is no pay for the guaranteed overtime that each staff member has to do, the pay disparities by race and gender are a huge problem with people secretly getting a pay rises to even out the data before it is released to the public. No clear pathway for pay rises with favourites being given pay rises and other extremely hard-working staff who go above and beyond being turned down due to budget. 

-Progression – there is what appears to be a linear line from entering as an associate, progressing to senior associate, to then manager and then getting to director level. Things are not what they seem, with promotions internally being based of who you know and if your line manager puts in a good word for you, without these things’ promotions are extremely hard to get. 

- Training - there are no streamlined training support given to new starters on how to use the systems and what is expected or for new line managers who can have teams of 7+ with no line management experience, it really is sink or swim. 

-	Diversity and inclusion – there are several network groups for protected characteristics, for example LGBTQ, BAME, Women’s. Yet these are run by lower staff for no extra pay, recognition, possible promotion or support. Plus, there is no training to be a network lead unless forcibly begging for it. Hilary the CEO attends monthly meetings with all networks leads however no real actions for change that are suggested by the leads is ever taken into account, instead the new culture director steals these ideas and passes them off as her own. (You know who you are!)
There are several other internal and external groups that are lead by directors, staff get great updates on the discussions that have taken place, yet no tangible action for improvement is ever made. This is probably because the D&I team are made up of white middle class employees who don’t think that tangible change is needed. 

-	Reviews – these Glassdoor reviews have been a huge contention for internal staff, with old employees asked to write positive reviews of Ambition to offset all the negative, so be careful what positive reviews you trust about Ambition. The main reason for this was that funders were worried about the severe level of negative reviews, however the negative reviews reflect the real internal workings. 

-	Director level and above – as noted directors often steal work and take credit, speak horrendously about other staff members and expect everyone to often work 10+ hour days. However, they themselves are subject to pressure from above and are often online at 10pm onwards just trying to keep a float.

-	HR – the ever criticised HR Team, do try their best, however with the level of staff turn over in that department it is hard to keep up, as well as the resistance from the CEO to actually make any improvements to the company. 

In conclusion, I am thrilled to say I no longer work here, it was great to start with but then when the illusion fell it was clear that this is a company that has no clear direction, changes focus and strategy every year (future teachers, middle leadership programme, Apprentices , NPQS, ECT…the list could go on). As well as changing names and branding each year (Future Teachers, Ambition School Leadership, Ambition Institute). 
If you want to work in the Education and charity section, look elsewhere, if you are a young 20 something and just want a job to get you by then this is the place as there is no long term reward or support to stay long term. 
Be warned though that you may have to work ridiculous hours, your ideas probably will be stolen and passed off as someone else's, you may have complaints filled against you just for giving ideas that are then stolen by others and you will probably be spoken down to and at some point made cry at the complete mess that is Ambition Institute….hopefully this review helps internal and potential employers to look else where.

pros: There are no pros to working at Ambition
cons:
I worked at Ambition, and its legacy organisations for over 7 years. In my final 2 years, they treated me dreadfully, and I can’t recommend enough that you do everything you can to avoid working there. There are several issues I want to draw attention too, many of which have been touched upon by other posters: 

1.	Toxic culture since the merger 
Since the merger of Ambition School Leadership and Institute of Teaching, there has been a dreadful culture. Of course, it is hard to unite opposing ideologies (even intentionally!), but instead, IfT began by being oppositional to Ambition School Leadership. In particular, IfT staff were encouraged to view Ambition School Leadership staff critically, which planted seeds amongst the IfT staff not to trust Ambition staff, and to view their work as sub-par. When I have worked with individuals in many instances, I built good relationships. However, the bad culture still exists between these teams- namely: the current design team and the programmes that fall under the 'teaching' programmes umbrella vs all other teams within the organisation. These teams work with the rest of the organisation in a conflictual manner, either micromanaging work, advising on areas outside of their expertise, or trying to take on responsibilities that doesn't sit within their functions. 

2.	No viable operating model, or organisational strategy 
The organisation has been running into a deficit each year (which you can see publically on companies house). In spite of this, there has been no clear strategy to address this. These issues lead to continual organisational restructures (3 in the last 2 years), where senior staff are protected and junior staff let go, in spite of where there is evidence to the contrary about who does the work. E.g. the School Partnerships team removed all junior-level postings this year, with no evidence on why this was a better model. 

3.	Incompetent CEO 
Hilary has shown absolutely no organisational leadership since joining the organisation and is clearly out of her depth. For a while, it was hoped that she was holding her cards to her chest while finding her feet, but unfortunately, she has not made decisive action on any area and continued to oversee an organisation with no model, and a terrible culture. Only with new leadership can Ambition improve. 

4.	Unethical & incompetent HR 
This year my job was coming to an end, as it was a maternity cover contract. The organisation decided to place me in a redeployment pool, which means any suitable role that came up, I would be considered first as a candidate. When a new hire was announced one day, I asked HR why I hadn’t been able to apply for the role, they told me the internal intranet post, was the first they had heard of the vacancy, and said it was ‘out of their hands’. I was then called by an exec director who explained it was just a ‘3 month’ posting, which is why it didn’t go through due process. This was in direct contradiction to the postholder, who said in a call with me that she was expected to be here until December (9 months at the time- going well beyond my contract end date). This postholder is still employed. 

When I complained formally about this, I was lied to repeatedly by HR and leadership. The complaint put me out of favor of the organisation, and when suitable posts did come up, the process was predetermined so that I was unsuccessful. When I emailed Hilary to discuss these issues she ignored me on several occasions. 

Whilst there is one particular good HR employee (Janine) and perhaps others in HR are trying to influence the organisation to do better, the fact that the organisational leadership is not listening to the advice of HR (or the law), nor providing enough resource for it (for instance they have not backfilled the role of HR director) shows how little they respect HR. 

Now when you read this, you may just think I am a ‘disgruntled’ employee, but it is not just me that feels this way. The results of the staff survey that came out this year compared us with other charities. Across most metrics we were in the bottom quartile, yet Ambition took no action to respond to the feedback.

review_title: Ironic 'charity' promoting the primacy of leadership externally while having a  black hole void of it internally
pros:
Smart, talented and very amicable staff
Smartly straddles taking in lucrative government contracts with development of  independently funded and ran corporate programmes £££
Long-term organisational capacity deficits create opportunities to take additional 'development opportunities' outside of your contract and often in your spare time, whether you chose to take these or they are thrust upon you under the guise of 'organisational need'. If you do not have a life outside of work or looking to give one up, Ambition School Leadership may just be for you.
cons:
Appalling HR- I mean,  truly appalling.  
Wage depression
Work-life balance
Palpable low morale

What can I say? If you value  even a degree of balance in your life do not work for Ambition School Leadership.  Prior to the merger I was on the Future Leaders side where there was a worrying culture of overworking but with an appreciation to dedicated staff. Since the merger, the workload has again increased substantially and the obsession with performance management targets is truly suffocating and counterproductive.  

It is also worth noting that the pay of roles advertised is substantially lower than when I started at the end of 2015, whereas expectations and the workload has increased.  Internal promotion opportunities have also dried up considerably. A classic case of layers of management who have done enough boot-licking up to middle and senior management only to subsequently knock the ladder down behind them and having no shame in throwing those below them under the bus.

Morale across the organisation is palpably low. The internal propaganda machine which  shovels disingenuous talk of 'values', 'mission' and 'moral purpose' down our throats has worn thin, especially as since the merger it is painstakingly and cringeworthilly conceited and inauthentic.  Comparison with North Korea or the Soviet Union always comes to mind, however outrageously hyperbolic, but this is a five year plan that needs abolishing.

The HR department are grossly incompetent to the point of countless breaches of employment law, Careless confidentiality breaches of sensitive employer information littered on it's shared drive and around the office printer.

I do believe, especially on the Future Leaders side there used to be heart to what we were trying to achieve. It's probably no coincidence that problems have been mounting as the focus has shifted relentlessly to chasing money.

I hope these are teething problems with establishing a new organisation but to ambitious, morally-driven graduates and those early on in their career, I'd advise staying well away if you can help it, for now at least. With hindsight I would never have worked here, let alone on currently advertised salaries. You can do better.

pros:
Culture: I truly believe we have an outstanding culture here; I can’t tell you how empowering it is to walk into work knowing that your opinions, thoughts and ideas will not only be heard but taken into account. It doesn’t feel hierarchical and there isn’t a culture of fear; in my opinion people are encouraged to be themselves. This wasn’t the case in my previous job where I would often feel patronised and belittled by senior colleagues. I love working for Ambition for a bunch of reasons but it’s the people that give me the most pride; to work amongst so many kind, supportive and talented individuals who go out of their way to support you is invaluable.

Learning and Development: When I joined our predecessor organisation (Teaching Leaders) as a Delivery Associate, I got stuck in and learnt all about our programmes, matrix working and how to interview and assess candidates, which I really enjoyed. When we became Ambition, I saw a role in the Marketing and Comms team that really excited me. Even though I had no direct experience, my now manager gave me the opportunity to grow into the role through multiple learning and development opportunities. I’m learning technical skills that I never thought would be in my reach and feel much more confident in facilitation and building professional relationships. That being said, learning opportunities haven’t been handed to me on a plate. The opportunities are there, but you need to be proactive and go for it. 

Agile working: I love the fact we have agile working here as it really suits my working style. I used to hate feeling like my days were confined to the same four walls.  The opportunity to work agilely gives me me the autonomy to set up a working week that works for me. It also makes me feel like the organisation trusts me; something that I hadn’t experienced in other work situations.
cons:
Reactive : As we’re a new organisation, sometimes it feels like we are quite fast paced. I know this is normal after a merger but it can be frustrating at times, especially when we could have done something more impactful. 

Take time to reflect: Sometimes as an organisation we forget to pause and reflect on what we’ve achieved or what we could have done better etc. I think we miss a trick sometimes as we are charging ahead without looking around us. That’s when mistakes can happen.

review_title: Lamentable organisation masquerading as a charity
pros: Associate level staff, who as a rule, are more than the organisation deserve in terms of skills, experience and general empathy.
cons:
Everything. Another reviewer has raised the point about the irony of an organisation which promotes the benefits of excellent leadership externally and then pursues the exact opposite approach internally. It's as though discovering the President of the Galileo society, is, infact, a flat earth theorist.

I cannot underemphasise how awful an organisation this is to work for. I've witnessed employment law flagrantly broken, staff with mental health concerns sneered at, confidential information about employees leaked and employees being coerced into working appalling hours in the interests of 'organisational need'. 

This organisation requires root and branch reform. Every member of Exco appears, either through accident or design, unwilling or incapable of dealing with the inconvenient business of actually running a functional organisation. There are a subsequent layer of Associate Directors, who essentially deal with the tasks that Exco feel are beneath them, which would be fine other than the fact these people owe their careers to the patronage they have enjoyed (to wit - who these individuals have been prepared to schmooze for a promotion). Then, below this, you have a cadre of managers, of varying abilities, who recognising the organisation's deference to power will willingly throw their team under a bus in order to climb one step further on the management rung. 
These are broad generalisations but generally they ring true of an organisation that would rather 'appear' to be doing a great job than it would, actually do a great job. 
Furthermore, the entire structure is run and organised on the basis of a now fundamentally discredited 'performance management' model of operating. Performance targets rule the roost. The problem, of course, is that human experience, particularly that within education is not simply a set of one's and Zeros. As Robert McNamara proved, if you can't win a war on performance targets you certainly can't counter educational disadvantage that way either.

The finances are a mess. Department for education need to stop funding the salaries of egotistical, white exec team and give to schools.

review_title: Hypocrisy thy name is Ambition School Leadership
pros: It’s located in Central London. The park in Lincoln’s Inn Fields is quite pleasant I suppose. The Associate Level staff, are as a rule, an incredibly affable and dedicated group of individuals.
cons:
Everything else. Having worked there for an extended period of time it’s difficult to escape the impression that the entire edifice has been constructed to massage the egos of some Oxbridge types short of a job. Unfortunately, this lip service to a poorly defined charitable ‘mission’ has resulted in a group of mediocrities in the mid-tier of the organisation cleaving to a facsimile of ‘success’ in the hope that they too will inducted into the rarified air of power and infuence. Unlikely. The entire organisation’s existence is yet another testament to Oxbridge’s monopolistic stranglehold on the rhythms of British society at large.
As a result a cadre of talented, hard-working and intelligent staff at lower levels of the organisation are treated abysmally by a group of people who couldn’t manage the proverbial in a brewery. Internal promotion is run along feudal lines where career advancement seems largely determined  by the favour of powerful benefactor. It’s clear that the self-aggrandising ‘mission’ about equal opportunity and meritocracy hasn’t percolated down to the organisation’s policy on salary for Associate level staff, where the contempt in which you are regarded is routinely revealed on the 25th of every month when wage slips arrive.  No quality evidence or research at all that the perpetual motion machine that is Ambition School Leadership delivers anything of meaning or value in the education sector except to act as an extremely effective sluice of public money into the hands of monstrously overpaid and dubiously qualified external education ‘consultants.’ They do let you wear your own jeans on a Friday though. So there is that.
